metadata.title: Inclusion of nano metakaolin as additive in ultra high performance concrete (UHPC)

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Inclusion of nano metakaolin as additive in ultra high performance concrete (UHPC)
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2016.09.127 0950-0618/ 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: norhasri@gmail.com (M.S. Muhd Norhasri), hmohdsaman@ yahoo.com (M.S. Hamidah), fadiil2003@yahoo.com (A. Mohd Fadzil), megawatiomar@yahoo.com (O. Megawati).
M.S. Muhd Norhasri a,⇑, M.S. Hamidah a, A. Mohd Fadzil a, O. Megawati b a Faculty of Civil Engineering, Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM), Shah Alam, Selangor, Malaysia bAcademy of Language Studies, Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM), Shah Alam, Selangor, Malaysia
h i g h l i g h t s
To characterise the cementitious properties of nano metakaolin as additive in UHPC. To optimise the mix formulation of UHPC embedded with nano metakaolin. To investigate the workability of nano metakaolined UHPC as additive. To investigate the strength development for nano metakaolined UHPC. To investigate the morphology of nano metakaolined UHPC and compare with plain OPC and metakaolined UHPC.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 27 June 2016 Received in revised form 29 August 2016 Accepted 28 September 2016
Keywords: UHPC Nano metakaolin Workability Compressive strength Morphology
a b s t r a c t
The utilisation of nano particles to enhance concrete can be seen in its densification and refining. In this study, nano metakaolined UHPC mixes were used as an additive range of 1%, 3%, 5%, 7%, 9% and 10% from cement weight. All UHPC specimens were compared to the plain UHPC and metakaolined UHPC mixes. The effect of nano metakaolined UHPC was evaluated in the forms of workability in fresh state, strength property and the morphology of the microstructure in the UHPC. The determination of the fresh property was conducted by a workability test. Meanwhile, the strength property was conducted by compressive strength in 3, 7 and 28 days. Next, the morphology in the UHPC microstructure was analysed by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). The uniqueness and difference morphology formation was analysed and compared to the plain UHPC. It can then be concluded that the nano metakaolined UHPC mix contributed to a low workability effect due to its clay properties and ultrafine size as compared to the OPC and metakaolin. The inclusion of nano metakaolin in UHPC shows similar compressive strength at early age but gradually increased at later ages as compared to the plain UHPC and metakaolined UHPC.
2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ultra High Performance Concrete (UHPC) is one of the concrete types that are being used in construction today. Before UHPC was invented, High Strength Concrete (HSC) whose the compressive strength is between 50 and 90 MPa was popular to be used in concrete design [1,2]. The HSC started to develop in construction in the 80’s and the mix formulation was designed based on a mathematical approach and then finalised to HSC formulation and obtained by BS-EN and ASTM standard [3,4]. The HSC strength enhancement is gained with the help of additive such as silica fume, metakaolin
and ground granulated blast furnace (GGBS). In addition, the selection on raw materials such as quartz and basalt also influences the HSC strength properties by increasing the strength due to high siliceous properties. Moreover, the hardness of quartz and basalt which is higher than granite also improves the strength properties of UHPC [2,5,6].
Since the new millennium, researchers’ interest has grown to produce more durable and high strength concrete. The UHPC must achieve compressive strength higher than 150 MPa [7–9]. In achieving these properties, the selection of fine aggregates should be less than 10 mm [10–12]. This is to ensure a pack component and fewer voids created during the mixing can be achieved. Also, it is to note that there is a high content of cement used in preparing the UHPC [10,13,14]. In addition, pozzolan is required material to achieve the target strength. Silica fume is the popular pozzolanic material used in UHPC mix due to its fine particle. 98% of silica
component provides a better strength compared to the OPC and other types of pozzolanic material [15,16].
To note, there are numerous addition of metakaolin in the UHPC and the performance is slightly lower than the silica fume [17,18]. However, the metakaolin effect on the durability properties is claimed to have been better than the OPC and silica fume [19,20]. Hence, in this study, the effect on strength properties of the metakaolin in UHPC was determined. The inclusion of nano particles as additive in UHPC was also introduced.
Nano comes from a Greek word which means dwarf or small [21,22]. Since the 80’s the ideas to convert micro based materials into nano particles grew and it has helped to improve the quality of human life. The utilisation of nano technology in human daily routine has become more prominent in biotechnology, electronic, medical appliances and military equipment. In concrete, the addition of nano materials started with the blooming utilisation of UHPC in the construction industry. Theoretically, the addition of nano materials in concrete is to improve the microstructure of UHPC and create a neat and uniform component of concrete with less pores and voids. Studies on the pore volume in concrete is not intensively explored but it is well known that the microstructure of concrete is porous [23,24]. In order to overcome the problem, micro-based material such as pozzolanic material is incorporated in the concrete. Pozzolanic material shows a huge impact in reducing the porosity problem for normal and high strength concrete. However, for packed component in the microstructure of UHPC, the addition of micro-based material shows a slow effect in improving its performance. In normal concrete and the HSC, void and pore problems occur between the cement pastes, but in the UHPC, the problem is extended to the calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) structure [25–27]. The C-S-H gel in concrete is known as nano structures [28–30]. The uniformity of the C-S-H gel will ensure the performance of the concrete. The performance of the UHPC would be enhanced and durability properties can be gained by modifying the C-S-H structures. Micro base material, especially silica fume, shows a good UHPC enhancement.
The inclusion of silica fume in modifying the C-S-H structure was explored and reported [31,32]. However, other pozzolanic material such as metakaolin has not been revealed extensively. This lack of exploration generated the idea of introducing nano particles in UHPC. It is hypothesized that the nano particle perhaps can improve the UHPC structure by producing a better and more uniform C-S-H gel.
Hence in this study, the utilisation of nano metakaolin and metakaolin in UHPC was then experimented. At present, extensive research on nano metakaolin and metakaolin in UHPC, especially the crystal formation in the microstructure, has not been disclosed. Having smaller particle effect as a nano filler is hypothesized to be able to produce a more densified UHPC mix, which in turn enhances its performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of raw material
sections.text:
The preparation of raw materials in this study is discussed briefly in this section. Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC) for this research was procured by YTL (M) Sdn Bhd. Fine aggregates was procured from river sand and sieved using a 4.75 mm sieve to remove the silt and clogging particles. Meanwhile, the 10 mm coarse aggregate, which was granite, was selected. To maintain the freshness of the UHPC mix, a Glenium Ace Suretec 389 hyper plasticizer was applied. It was supplied by BASF (M) Sdn. Bhd. The kaolin was supplied by AKI (M). To transform kaolin into nano kaolin, Fritsch High Energy Milling was used to perform milling
process. For milling process, zirconia jar and ball was used in order to avoid heat during milling. Fifteen 5 mm balls were selected. The duration of milling was 24 h at a speed of 400 revolution per minute (rpm). The final size for nano metakaolin was confirmed using a Fritsch Laser Particle Analyser and the final size was 176 nano meter (nm). Using the same instrument, the size of kaolin was detected as 5.5 lm meter (lm). Finally, the nano kaolin and metakaolin underwent a calcination process to change into nano metakaolin and metakaolin. The duration and temperature of the calcination process was 3 h at 700 C for both samples. Table 1 shows the chemical composition and Table 2 shows the particles size of cementitious materials used in this study with the surface area of cementitious material by using Fritsch laser particle analyser. From Table 1 proves that the silica and alumina content in the nano metakaolin have increased as compared to the OPC, metakaolin and nano kaolin. Apart from that, the effective size for nano metakaolin was detected and smaller than other cementitious materials. Based on this analysis, calcination of nano metakaolin improved to reduce the size and increased the pozzolanic reactivity of nano metakaolin by increasing the silica and alumina component. Fig. 1.1 shows the XRD analysis for kaolin, nano kaolin and nano metakaolin. The kaolinite content of nano kaolin and nano metakaolin is increased as compared to the kaolin and metakaolin. This is confirmed by the peak shows in Fig. 1.1. In other words, the transformation of crystal into amorphous phase for nano kaolin into nano metakaolin was confirmed.

sections.heading: 3.1. Finalisation of the UHPC mix proportion
sections.text:
Since there is no standard design mix for a UHPC, the final mix designed in this study was finalised based on the Matte and Morranville (1999) series of trial mixes. The decision to select this mix was conducted on the cement content by Matte which were the lowest among other researchers [10,11]. However, the final design mix in this study was modified in order to create a new design mix for the UHPC that captured with the moderate cement, using normal type of aggregates and achieved compressive strength at day 28 more than 150 MPa.
Table 3 shows the difference between the Matte mix and the present author’s mix after undergoing modification. In addition, the basis of this new design mix used in this study has undergone a series of trial mixes to achieve the targeted compressive strength mentioned before [8,13,33].

sections.heading: 3.2. Preparation, mixing and handling of raw materials and UHPC specimens
sections.text:
The final mix proportion for this study was tabulated in Table 4. The mixing was commenced by preparing the paste of the UHPC. A
Table 2 Particle size and surface area for cementitious materials.
Sample Effective size, D10 (nm) D30 (nm) D60 (nm) Mean Size (nm) Percentage of nano particles (<500 nm) Surface Area (m2/kg)
OPC 2433 6954 10,972 12,428 – 12,748 Metakaolin 1612 5585 13,325 12,052 – 18,231 Nano Metakaolin 176 395 767 1114 40 140,792
Fig. 1.1. XRD analysis for kaolin, metakaolin, nano kaolin and nano metakaolin.
Mix Cement (kg/m3) Fine (kg/m3) Coarse (kg/m3) SP (kg/m3) Water (kg/m3) Nano metakaolin (kg/m3) Metakaolin (kg/m3)
OPC 800 433 800 16 160 – – MK10 720 433 800 16 160 – 80 NMKA1 720 433 800 16 160 8 80 NMKA3 720 433 800 16 160 24 80 NMKA5 720 433 800 16 160 40 80 NMKA7 720 433 800 16 160 56 80 NMKA9 720 433 800 16 160 72 80
high speed mixer was used to ensure homogeneity to the mix. Cement and water were poured together with the nano metakaolin. Next, while the machine was rotating, a hyper plasticizer was introduced and time was allowed until all constituents were formed into a paste. The process to prepare the paste took around 3–5 min. After the paste was prepared, fine aggregate was added immediately to it while the mixer was rotating. Then mixing of the fine aggregate and paste continued until the mix became uniformly blended and consistent. This mixing took around 5–10 min. Finally, coarse aggregate was added to the mix and the machine continued to rotate another 5–10 min until the concrete uniformly blended and consistent. After the UHPC mix was prepared, it was poured into the mould and was vibrated to remove the air bubbles. To determine the compressive strength of these UHPC specimens, 100 mm steel cube was used. After the vibrating process, the UHPC
mix was covered with gunny sack to avoid moisture losses and left for 24 h. After 24 h, it was demoulded and placed in water and cured until the age of testing which was 3, 7 and 28 days.
Testing for fresh property was conducted by a slump test soon after the UHPC mix was prepared. The evaluation of slump test was based on the targeted slump indicator which was 60–180 mm slump. Immediately at the age of testing, the compressive strength was conducted using an ELE 3000 machine. Finally, Fritsch Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM) with EDX analysis was used to visualise the micrograph image for the microstructure properties for the UHPC specimens. This was to evaluate the crystal formation for the UHPC specimens. In all, this study compared the workability, strength and morphology of nano metakaolined UHPC specimens to the plain and metakaolined UHPC’s.

sections.heading: 4.1. Workability of UHPC
sections.text:
The effect on workability of nano metakaolin into UHPC is shown in Fig. 1.2. Generally, data tabulated in Fig. 1.2 shows a decrease in workability with the inclusion of nano metakaolin and metakaolin. The decrease occurred due to the inclusion of nano metakaolin. This shows that the addition of nano metakaolin at every level of inclusion has reduced the slump reading as compared to OPC and MK10. The higher the amount of nano metakaolin, the lower the slump reading is. In the experiment, the slump reading was reduced and shown by the NMKA9 mix which underwent 9% inclusion of nano metakaolin.
The slump reading of the NMKA9 was 150 mm which was the lowest among all mixes. The highest slump in this study was 178 mm, which was recorded by the OPC. While plain UHPC recorded the slump reading at 166 mm in slump. This can be concluded that adding the nano metakaolin reduced the workability of UHPC as compared to the OPC and MK10 mixes. This occurrence could be due to the size of nano metakaolin which had increased the surface area of the UHPC mix. Its clay properties also provided the absorption effect. This absorption effect increased the water demand which in turn made the mixes drier due to the loss water consumed by the nano metakaolin during mixing. At a higher percentage of nano metakaolin, the slump reading was lower which was also due to water losses, absorbed by the nano metakaolin, in the mixing. The sizes of particles provided a huge impact in the workability of UHPC as in the nano metakaolin mixes. It was confirmed that the smaller particle had provided more surface area to be covered which reduced the workability behaviour of the UHPC.

sections.heading: 4.2. Strength property of nano metakaolined UHPC
sections.text:
To determine the UHPC strength property, a compressive strength was selected as a strength indicator. In this case, all nano metakaolined specimens were compared to a plain UHPC which was coded OPC and metakaolined UHPC coded MK10. While the nano metakaolined UHPC specimens were coded NMKA and the numbers behind them indicated the percentage of the addition of nano metakaolin between 1% and 9%. The strength properties of the nano metakaolined UHPC specimens were evaluated from 3, 7 and 28 days of testing ages.
Fig. 1.3 shows the effect of nano metakaolined on the UHPC after 3 days of testing. Adding different percentage of nano metakaolin shows a slow reaction in the strength enhancement as compared to the OPC and MK10 specimens. The highest compressive strength recorded by the NMKA1 mix that had 1% of nano
metakaolin. A compressive strength recorded by the NMKA1 was higher than the MK10 mix but slightly lower than the OPC.
It can be seen that adding nano metakaolin to UHPC did not improve its early strength. This trend occurred due to the packed component in the UHPC mix that provided less pores between the cement and the aggregate. Those packed component retarded the filling process of the nano metakaolin and metakaolin. This behaviour was reported by Shakir, which proves that nano metakaolin did not influenced on the early strength effect due to the incomplete filler effect in the packed component of UHPC [34,35]. On the other hand, 10% inclusion of metakaolin had enhanced the strength as compared to the other UHPC mixes except for the OPC and NMKA1 specimens. This shows that the micro filler effect did not blend well with the UHPC. Since the microstructure of the UHPC was compact with finer material, adding metakaolin did not strengthen it on day 3. Nor did a higher addition of nano metakaolin improve the UHPC strength properties. Although the size of nano metakaolin was in a nano form, in the higher addition of metakaolin the incomplete filling process occurred and provided non hydrated spot which loosened the bond between the cement and the aggregate. The incomplete filling process also affected the densifying process of the UHPC and created more pores between the cement due to the flocculation of the non hydrated nano particles. However, a low addition of nano metakaolin, which was 1% shows the optimum strength enhancement as compared to the other nano metakaolin mixes. A low inclusion proves to be sufficient to provide a moderate ultrafilling effect in densifying the UHPC. On day 3, inclusion of nano metakaolin was to perform as an ultra-filler agent in refining the UHPC. The strength of the UHPC caused by the nano metakaolin was accomplished by the filling process that had provided a denser UHPC microstructure and also can be initiated by accelerating effect in cement hydration.
Apart from that, a compressive strength of the UHPC contained nano metakaolin on day 7 is shown in Fig. 1.3. At a glance, the pattern on day 7 shows a similar strength behaviour performed on day 3. However, Fig. 1.3 shows that, the inclusion of nano metakaolin displays an increase in the compressive strength other than the NMKA1 specimen. Generally, on day 7, the OPC specimens still performed the highest compressive strength as compared to the MK10 specimen and nano metakaolined UHPC specimens. The compressive strength of the OPC was recorded at 148 MPa and followed by the NMKA1 mix at 146 MPa. From here we can see that the inclusion of nano metakaolin in the UHPC does not improve the strength as compared to the control specimens (OPC).
The interesting finding was that there was a small difference in the compressive strength between the OPC and the NMKA1 specimens. This shows that the pozzolanic reaction performed by
the nano metakaolin was started to react in the UHPC. However, the formation of pozzolanic reaction was little and not sufficient to enhance the strength of the UHPC. The MK10 compressive strength was increased but the measurement was still lower as compared to the OPC, NMKA1 and also other NMKA specimens (with the exception of NMKA3). From this finding it shows that the strength enhancement from the inclusion of nano metakaolin continues to grow the filling process with a pozzolanic reaction in a minimal formation. The strength of NMKA3 was lower as compared to the other UHPC specimens due to the incomplete filling process through 3% inclusion of nano metakaolin embedded in UHPC. The incomplete filling process in the NMKA3 specimen created a non hydrated spot between the cement and the nano metakaolin.
The other nano metakaolin mixes had problem with the non hydrated spots but not as severe as that of in the NMKA3 specimen. That layer, called non-hydrated nano particle, had increased the density and covered the surface of the cement paste. This was the action that affected the strength of the nano metakaolin UHPC on day 7. The rise of the NMKA1 strength accrued from the adequate filling effect in refining the UHPC component. A low addition of nano metakaolin shows an adequate reaction in refining the surface of the UHPC. On the other hand, too much inclusion of nano metakaolin will cause a homogeneity and uniformity in the UHPC microstructure.
Fig. 1.3 shows the observation on the compressive strength of the UHPC on day 28. The highest strength recorded at this age was shown by the NMKA1 specimen which is 178 MPa. This strength shows a better enhancement as compared to the OPC with a compressive strength of 165 MPa. The other specimens such as MK10, NMKA5 and NMKA7 show a better strength enhancement as compared to the OPC (except for NMKA3 and NMKA9 specimens). The nano metakaolin increased strength was from the formation of pozzolanic reaction in the UHPC component which provided the additional C-S-H gels that bind the cement component thoroughly. The formation of pozzolanic reaction was evaluated from the unique form of crystal structure provided by the nano metakaolin, especially shown by the NMKA1 specimen. Since particles of nano metakaolin which was flaky, elongated, thin and platy provided that needle action system in reinforcing the cement component. As for MK10 specimen, the needle action was identified only in the bigger needle structure. Its reduction of pores was limited as compared to the nano metakaolin particles.
As a conclusion, the effect of nano metakaolin on the UHPC could be seen in two phases. The first action caused by nano metakaolin was the filling effect which occurred between day 3 and 7. In this phase, the UHPC strength was obtained from a uniform formation of the filling process which refined the pore structure of the CS-H gel. The second was the reaction of the pozzolanic reaction caused by the silica and alumina constituents in the nano metakaolin, which reacted with the calcium hydroxide in the cement. The reaction of pozzolanic occurred on day 28 which took place immediately after the refining at early age. The formation of the pozzolanic reaction had provided the additional C-S-H structure and refined the existing C-S-H structure, which in turn improved the bonding between the cement pastes in the UHPC.

sections.heading: 4.3. Micrograph analysis
sections.text: In this section, the crystal formation and other transformation in the microstructure of the UHPC were monitored by images and compared to the OPC. The analysis on the crystal formation is described from the images captured by SEM and was evaluated between day 3 and 28.

sections.heading: 4.4. Analysis on day 3
sections.text:
Fig. 1.4a–g show the micrograph images of the UHPC microstructure on day 3. The microstructure of the OPC is shown in Fig. 1.4a. We can see that the surface of the OPC specimen was uneven and the granular particles majored the formation of the OPC specimen. At this age, the C-S-H crystals were not seen clearly but the bonding between the cement and the aggregate was neat although not well-organised. The appearance of the crystals which bound the cement and the aggregate was shown by the whitish spots (Fig. 1.4a). The formation of those spots shows that the microstructure binding process was executed in the packed component in the UHPC. The visible pores were minimal and covered by the C-S-H gel, hence triggering the strength enhancement of the OPC.
Meanwhile, Fig. 1.4b shows the micrograph image of the MK10 mix. A different surface analysis was presented by the MK10 mix. The inclusion of 10% metakaolin in the MK10 mix shows a smoother UHPC surface as compared to the OPC. A smoother surface generated by the metakaolin was monitored by flaky flakes of metakaolin inserted between the cement particles. This trend was not seen in the OPC image which shows that the refining process occurred after the UHPC was paired with the metakaolin. The whitish spots indicated the appearance of the C-S-H crystal that differed from the metakaolin addition. In the MK10, greyish spots were spotted showing that the formation of C-S-H crystal was paired with the metakaolin flakes. However, the strength of the MK10 was lower as compared to the OPC and this occurred due to filler effect from the metakaolin. During this age, the micro filler effect was the only action on day 3 that triggered the strength without the assistance from any pozzolanic reaction and the C-SH gel.
The micrograph of UHPC incorporated with 1% of nano metakaolin was shown in Fig. 1.4c. A smoother surface was shown. A worthy finding was the formation of C-S-H crystal which started to grow to provide additional reinforcing system in the UHPC. However, this strength was similar or slightly lower than that of the OPC due to the formation of the crystal from the nano metakaolin, which occurred only for the filling process. Further, in the UHPC packed component, the refining process was delayed due to the limited pores and voids to receive the nano metakaolin filling effect. The strength development in the NKAC1 was shown from the filler that refined the UHPC microstructure. This provided a better surface with less formation of pores as compared to the OPC and MK10 specimens.
Fig. 1.4d shows the micrograph of UHPC incorporated with 3% nano metakaolin. The flocculation of the non-hydrated particle was seen and this occurred due to the nano metakaolin particle which did not react uniformly between the cement and C-S-H gels. Only part of the nano metakaolin particle performed the refining process but due to the packed UHPC component, the remaining nano metakaolin was not inserted into the C-S-H gel, which created a layer outside and covered the surface of the cement and C-S-H gel. Therefore, the flocculation effect of the non-hydrated nano particle strength was affected due to the incomplete filling and dilution process.
Fig. 1.4e shows the effect of 5% inclusion of nano metakaolin. The refining process was seen to bind the cement particles. However due to the packed UHPC component, the dilution process of the nano metakaolin particles were delayed and this caused flocculation in the cement microstructure. This incomplete dilution process had not increased the strength. Instead, it created a layer that interfered with the binding process between the pore in the cement and the C-S-H gel. The strength was not improved due to the non-uniform formation of the C-S-H gel. Although increasing the nano metakaolin content showed a smoother UHPC surface,
the remaining non hydrated particle had created an uneven surface. This was shown by the spot of the non-hydrated particles of the NKAC5 specimen surface.
Fig. 1.4f shows the effect of UHPC incorporated with 7% nano metakaolin in the UHPC. It was clear that an increase in the nano metakaolin proved to refine the UHPC microstructure. This is shown in Fig. 1.4f whereby no visible pore is spotted that interfere the binding process of the cement and the C-S-H gel formation. All surfaces were covered uniformly and smaller crystal of C-S-H gel is seen during the refining process. The spot of non-hydrated particle was minimised showing that the dilution process of the 7% addition was tailored well with the UHPC component. However, the development of strength of the NKAC7 mix on day 3 was minimal as compared to the OPC. This happened due to the nano metakaolin particles at 7%, which combined well with the cement, acting as filler without the pozzolanic reaction. Pozzolanic reaction did not occur as filling the packed UHPC component was difficult. Here, the process of refining did not occur due to the limited space between the cement. However, inserting 7% nano metakaolin performed well in the filling process but only limited to the filler effect without any reaction with calcium hydroxide to trigger the pozzolanic reaction.
Fig. 1.4g shows the micrograph of UHPC incorporated with 9% of nano metakaolin. A similar pattern is shown in the NKAC9 and NKAC7. At a higher inclusion of nano metakaolin, finer surface was spotted showing that refining process occurring uniformly. A smoother surface of the NKAC9 is shown due to complete dilution effect. Also, less non hydrated particles problem was detected in NKAC9 mix. However, the strength increment was not impressive due to the action of nano metakaolin on day 3 which was only to refine the UHPC microstructure. Here, its combination with calcium hydroxide was delayed. The delay in the pozzolanic reaction occurred due to the insufficient nano metakaolin to react with the calcium hydroxide, which was used as filler on day 3.

sections.heading: 4.5. Analysis on day 28
sections.text:
The crystal growth of nano metakaolined UHPC on day 28 was presented in Fig. 1.5a–g. They are the results of the OPC as control specimens shown in Fig. 1.5a. A similar surface formation was compared on day 3 which was uneven and having granular particles on their surface on day 28. The figure also shows the C-S-H crystal which bound the cement component. However, the pores were not reduced hence a smoother surface could not be achieved. Without any filling agent from the additional material such as nano metakaolin or metakaolin, the process of refining the C-S-H structures was affected. The growth of the C-S-H crystal for the OPC was formed by the calcium hydroxide in the cement with the appearance of water. Since the content of silica and alumina in cement was limited, adequate formation of C-S-H gel was expected. Hence uneven surface of the UHPC appeared as there was no filler agent to penetrate and refine the C-S-H gel and cement.
The effect of metakaolin as cement replacement at 10% was shown in Fig. 1.5b. A UHPC better surface was formed with the help of the metakaolin as a cement replacement material. In this case a smoother surface was created. This shows that the refining process occurred immediately and the metakaolin action as a micro filler performed well in densifying the microstructure of the UHPC. A better densifying surface from the refining process facilitated to contribute a better strength. Crystal growth was seen but the size of the crystal was of a miniature form but would increase with a prolonged testing age.
Fig. 1.5c shows the micrograph of UHPC with the inclusion of 1% nano metakaolin. A better refining process was detected here. The formation of pozzolanic reaction was observed to have combined with the calcium hydroxide. This was the action that contributed
to the highest strength enhancement. Although the crystal growth was minimal and the size was small, a low addition of nano metakaolin was adequate to perform the filler effect and later to create the pozzolanic reaction which contributed to the high compressive strength. The pores between the cement and C-S-H gel were refined and densified with 1% of nano metakaolin.
Fig. 1.5d shows the micrograph of UHPC with the inclusion of 3% nano metakaolin. Larger spots of non-hydrated nano particle were detected on the surface of the NKAC3 specimen. Those spots were created due to the incomplete hydration process which provided flocculation hindrance. The increase in the non-hydrated particle affected the bind between the cement and it also loosened the bond of the cement matrix system. Here, the compressive strength was less enhanced which is inferior to those of the OPC or NKAC1 specimens.
Meanwhile, Fig. 1.5e shows the micrograph analysis of UHPC which was included with 5% of nano metakaolin. A smoother surface of UHPC was detected as compared to the NKAC3 but by increasing the nano metakaolin. The refining process was conducted from day 3. This process delayed the pozzolanic reaction which enhanced the strength. Better refining process caused by 5% inclusion of nano metakaolin was the factor that strengthened the NKAC5 mix as compared to the NKAC3. In addition, the strength of NKAC5 was slightly higher as compared to the OPC on day 28. This shows that a higher inclusion of nano metakaolin in UHPC will influence the strength due to filler effect. The pozzolanic reaction was continued but the reaction with the calcium hydroxide was decreasing due to the packed component in the UHPC. There was also insufficient nano metakaolin to promote the reaction with the calcium hydroxide [26].
Fig. 1.5e shows a repeating result shown in Fig. 1.5f. Fig. 1.5f shows the effect of 7% nano metakaolin in UHPC. It displays the compressive strength of the NKAC7 which was higher than the OPC. This strength increase occurred due to the refining process which continued on day 3 and performed the ultra-filling effect and improved the microstructure of the UHPC. The non-hydrated particle was minimized and the UHPC specimen was densified to generate stronger cement than that of the OPC.
Fig. 1.5g shows the micrograph analysis of UHPC incorporated with 9% inclusion of nano metakaolin. The surface of the NKAC9 mix was uneven and larger particles were seen on the surface and loosened the bond between the cement and the C-S-H gel. It is believed that if more than 9% of nano metakaolin was added, tendency of more non hydrated particles formation with nano particle will be created. Hence, those two actions affected the strength behaviour of the nano metakaolin in the UHPC. The non-hydrated nano particle increased the number of spots as seen in figure. The number of spots created was higher as compared to the other UHPC specimen. The filler effect was not created thus the crystal growth was not uniform.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The conclusion of this study is drawn as follows:
1. The inclusion of nano metakaolin reduced the workability of UHPC specimens as compared to OPC. Since, the particle of nano metakaolin was smaller, the surface area of the UHPC specimens was increased which in turn and reduced the UHPC workability. Further, the nano metakaolin particle, which was from clay, functioned in the water absorption. The water content was affected causing a low workability with respect to a higher content of nano metakaolin. 2. Secondly, the inclusion of nano metakaolin showed a stronger late effect of the compressive strength. On days 3 and 7, the inclusion of nano metakaolin in the UHPC performed a filler
effect which refined and densified the UHPC microstructure. On day 28, the compressive strength of the nano metakaolin started to enhance and show a better strength as compared to the OPC and MK10 specimens. 3. The 1% inclusion of nanometakaolin charted the optimum effect in the compressive strength. The acts which contributed to the strength development were the filling effect on days 3–7 and the pozzolanic reaction that started after 14 days of age. 4. The C-S-H crystal of nano metakaolin was different as compared to the OPC and the MK10 mixes. The OPC densified surface was generated through the formation of the uniform and homogeneous surface structure. However, the combination of ultra-filler with the pozzolanic reaction of the nano metakaolin was spotted by the unique sharp and thin crystal.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The authors would like to thank the Ministry of Education (MOE) which provided the scholarship and Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM). Our heartiest thanks also go to the faculty members of the Faculty of Civil Engineering, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Applied Science and the Academy of Language Studies that provided the instrument and support in pursuing this study.

metadata.abstractText: The utilisation of nano particles to enhance concrete can be seen in its densification and refining. In this study, nano metakaolined UHPC mixes were used as an additive range of 1%, 3%, 5%, 7%, 9% and 10% from cement weight. All UHPC specimens were compared to the plain UHPC and metakaolined UHPC mixes. The effect of nano metakaolined UHPC was evaluated in the forms of workability in fresh state, strength property and the morphology of the microstructure in the UHPC. The determination of the fresh property was conducted by a workability test. Meanwhile, the strength property was conducted by compressive strength in 3, 7 and 28 days. Next, the morphology in the UHPC microstructure was analysed by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). The uniqueness and difference morphology formation was analysed and compared to the plain UHPC. It can then be concluded that the nano metakaolined UHPC mix contributed to a low workability effect due to its clay properties and ultrafine size as compared to the OPC and metakaolin. The inclusion of nano metakaolin in UHPC shows similar compressive strength at early age but gradually increased at later ages as compared to the plain UHPC and metakaolined UHPC. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
